content.description:
Begin on a juggy flake and make strenuous moves trending up and left.  Reach for the slopey lip and press it out to a "Thank God" chicken head over the top.  Classic.

Anyone have a name for it?
content.protection: Several crashpads would be nice as the top is a bit committing.

content.description: Sit start half moon rail up to crimps and underclings to move into a left gaston in a finger crack, pull the gaston on thin feet to the flakes and over the edge.
content.location: Far right of the Gate boulder at the end of the Arrows at Ezel traverse.

content.description:
From the BB - Start in the low jug, same as Snatch, but go straight up avoiding the ‘Snatch’ feature to the left.

Excellent holds and feet until the end where it’s a bit more committing and reachy.
content.protection: 3 pads, uneven and a little rocky
content.location: On the East side of the Gate Boulder, starts just left of a head height rock that is next to The Gate Boulder

content.description: Start up thin edges and join the right-side arete to the top.

This silly fun problem from the BB starts on the left side of the Boulder on good holds with both toes hooked on slightly higher ledge to the right. Rotate under your legs to reach crimps to the right, then mantle over the far right side of the boulder. Bonus if you do a legit no hands bat hang in the middle.
content.location: On the south side of low wide boulder just west of the Gate Boulder.

content.description: Follow good crimps straight up the face. Crux right below lip, not such a good landing.
content.location: Start about 3 feet to the right of Left Side Direct.

content.description: The center-most line on the Gate Boulder's west face.  Tall with the hardest moves near the top.  Classic.
content.protection:
Put your

don't fall

cap on.

content.description: Stand start with two small crimps and make a big move to a good hold up and right.  Climb straight up the face using the arete with you left hand if necessary.  A great problem but a bit of a complicated landing...
content.protection: Crashpads and a spotter are a good idea.
content.location: This problem is found on the far left side of the Gate Boulder's west face.

content.description: Climb a funky chimney feature on the north end of the main boulder. Interesting moves.
From the Black Bible: "Start sitting in the pit on the right side of the arete. Climb Arete."
content.protection: 2-3 pads, landing is a little odd
content.location: On the tall triangular boulder just east of the north side of the Gate Boulder. This climb is on the south east arete.

content.description: Begin atop a sloping slab and make delicate moves up the crack topping out in the notch.  Feels pretty spicy looking at the landing!
content.protection: A crashpad or two though they may not do much if you fall.
content.location: On the left side of the Gate Boulder's south face.

content.description:
Classic Ian Glas traverse (though he may have started or finished slightly differently).  Start on the left variation of Surprise Ending.  Avoid the big ledge for your feet at the start.  At the positive edge at about 12 feet, cut right to the sharp incut jug.  Then drop down to the big jug flakes.  Head right through the sloping cracks and underclings.  Then follow the right leaning crack above the rock landing to a rest jug.  Continue right, under the tree (careful not to dab).  From the sidepull flake, do a powerful move to a perfect slimper.  Punch right to the juggy ledge feature.  Follow it all the way to the end, with a nice ergonomic top-out on a right hand pinch.  Video at

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yvY43bMWxa4

.

I am proposing 5.13 or V8/9 Traverse--MB (who grades stouter than me!) has suggested in the 5.12d/5.13a range.  I welcome other opinions on the grade.
content.protection: Numerous pads are helpful to make it feel safe.
